pros: Good MNC benefits, international experience/exposure
cons: Extremely unfair promotion/grading system. The company has a grading system, each employee has a grading from 10 to maybe 40... no one knows much about the grades (except our own) plus some hearsay. The truth is the grading in this company is based on the revenue size of the business division you are in and not based on loyalty, contribution, ownership, attitude, efforts, etc . its also not determine by your immediate supervisors or your management but by someone far away in either India or US. So to be promoted to the next grade, you need luck to... 1) to be in a divison that happens to make a certain revenue 2) have supportive management who have a network of other management (ether in HR, or someone with some power) to help sell your promotion to the committee 3) and pray that the committee is in a good mood when they review your case

Fast forward to 2 months on the job and HR still won’t tell you. Their website, if you hunt it down, says it will be determined by the leadership team when it’s time for employee evaluations. BUT GUESS WHAT? YOU ONLY GET THESE IF YOU STAY OVER 2 years. :/ -leadership sucks. They are not necessarily coming from a health care background, so why would they care about the patient let alone their workforce. - underpaid, grossly -abuse and toxicity -the list goes on, just sit outside and watch the employees when they leave from the office. review_title: Solid benefits, below average salary, horrible company culture and management.
pros: Pension is a plus. Good 401k match. Generous parental leave.
cons: The culture. Abbott treats their employees as if they’re disposable. They do not proactively promote or care about career development. Base salaries are also well below the industry standard. If you’re a member of the sales team, expect leadership to play games with the comp plan and not pay you what you earned. If they ask you to go above and beyond on something they say they will pay you for, get it in writing or they will backtrack and not do so. Middle and upper management is led by the worst people - they will micromanage and throw you under the bus to save their own skin while providing you little support. Management would rather be feared than loved. Leadership also likes to talk about strategy, but in reality they’re just financial/sales goals with no actual strategy on how they plan to achieve those goals. I’ve never worked for a company that had so many awful people in leadership positions. You will burn out and be miserable here in due time.

review_title: Toxic Workplace, Poor Management and Negative Company Culture.
pros: The employee engagement activities are nice but theres no interaction. They just give us free food.
cons:
Abbott is one of the worst medical manufacturing company. Division Structural Heart in the department Amplatzer is the worst. The managers, supervisors, and leads are incompetent which is negatively affecting both the work environment and company culture. 

The manager is hiring inexperienced and incompetent people placed in charge - the blind leading the blind. The manager and supervisors are also choosing people in their favor to take on more responsibilities and to become leads. They will not hire the experienced, competent, and top performers to become lead nor to give them more responsibilities. 

Play high in favoritism and politics. Lack of communication. High employee turnover rate and has a toxic work culture. 

- Teams and individuals are not able to collaborate effectively, let alone to build a high performing organization.
- Fail to supply promotions or raises for those with more experience and/or top performers. 
- Unhealthy work life balance where operators are working overtime regularly. 
- No proper training, tools, and development opportunities. 
- The manager and supervisor on first shift was seen in a meeting flirting with eachother. 
- Everything there seems like it's not working properly from your company badge of not being able to punch in to timecard machines reading your punches incorrectly to bad computer network and programming to poor working conditions in the dry room and more.
- All the machines are old with no workplace ergonomics. Employees complain about their fingers, hands, wrist, and backache are hurting. Where is all the money in this department?

Verbally Abusive and inexperienced managers with poor communication skills. Harassment, sexual harassment, a supervisor was seen viewing inappropriate media on the production floor on several occasions. This is a job I became injured at so I requested they change my duties temporarily as not to aggravate it ( not time off as I was entitled). I went to the doctor and was place on lidocaine patches, steroids and muscle relaxers 
 I couldn't take at work. They promptly ignored my work injury and as a result lost function of my right arm for 2 months unable to even lift my hand to drink a glass of water and no grip strength, all while leadership yells faster, faster on a bullhorn walking around you. Actual physical altercations broke out on many occasions leadership would finally push someone to a snapping point. The police would have to show up frequently. Generally a very depressing place to work. The contractors frequently botch checks and it takes weeks and weeks to rectify. A male person in a position of power over me made a very gross proposition to me while I was peacefully eating my lunch .

pros: World’s leading medical device company
cons:
Being an immigrant, it is really painful to be associated with Abbott.

I have worked for Abbott for 2 years and every other day, I used to work overtime and sometimes on weekends as well. I have been threatened by my manager that I may get fire for some typo errors in a document. I have been recognized cross functionally though.

Therefore, I left Abbott because of job insecurity and current form is trying to work on my green card petition and therefore, I need a job verification letter from Abbott. I have been trying for more than a month now but I have been told by the HR that it is not their policy to provide a job verification letter. I do not understand why they can’t especially when it is a requirement per the US government to file a green card petition. It’s really painful to get a revert from the Abbott team . I never thought that the world’s one of the top most company will not consider the pain of an immigrant and can jeopardize someone’s visa status.

review_title: Least Dysfunctional Company I have ever worked for
pros:
Positive professional attitude from the top down. Management good at focusing on forward-looking solutions rather than laying blame. 

Cooperative team dynamics. 

Receptive to flexible work schedules/work from home when family needs require (but they also expect a lot of overtime). 

Fair pay. Great benefits!

Lots of opportunities to learn new things. Company encourages skill and career development. 

Takes employee safety very seriously.
cons:
Lots of new acquisitions with messy integrations. Makes it difficult to affect necessary changes.

Have moved to a different building in different areas of the TC metro multiple times since I started. Very difficult to plan for commute.

Corporate often out of touch with operational needs of various divisions. 

Flexibility is good, but sometimes difficult to draw work/life boundaries. Lots of pressure to be available off the clock.

pros: Great solid and stable company.

pros: Monthly salary comes on agreed day.
cons:
Salary equality does not happen. There is no feedback system, so you are totally on mercy of your manager. Your development with career and salary can be finished by setting absurd goals. There is no way to inter act on them nor to “work with” the company. You will feel as a cost center and treated as one. 

This company lives so deep in seventies that it’s amazing it’s still standing. Internal management style is like dictatorship ( at least Europe / North).

Customers are claimed to be in focus, but these are just words in presentations. It is purely finance driven decision making, but here customers are mandatory burden to move towards goals. 

Company is constantly lacking resources due the reason that people leaves after they find out that they have been lied at the job interview. 
Job asd are professionally done as one can expect in big corporation, however whey you start in your position real job Is totally different. Do not buy that bonus scheme which shows that you double your salary when you exceed your goals by 10%. 50, 40, 30, precent growth targets on top of previous year is norm at the market which grows 1,5-3% organically per year. There are also positions where are same goals but you are locked with existing customers, so even less chances to pull out numbers.

pros: My boss was great; healthcare benefits were very affordable. Team structure was strong.
cons: You cannot trust the corporate benefits. On my benefits site, I had access to legal descriptions of 401k benefits that were not most up to date, but I did not know that until after I left. There was no indication that the corporate managed, personalized site was providing me with out of date documents. When deciding to leave, I based the decision in part on the vesting schedule described in that legal notice. After separation and numerous calls to the benefits department, I was informed that the document available to me was out of date and a legal statement saying they have the right to change it at any time meant that I had no way to tell that my vesting schedule had been changed after my hire date and no legal recourse. That means that I forfeited a portion of their contributions that I had every reason to believe were mine. I had entertained the idea that I may want to return someday, but now I know that I cannot trust the big, giant corporate entity. I will not consider working for them again. If I can't trust them to give me up to date information or live up to the conditions under which I was hired then they don't deserve my talent.

pros: As an overall company, Abbott does right by their employees. They will support you when emergencies happen and generally have your back. The vastness of the company allows for a relatively smooth transition between sites, cities, states, countries. The technology is groundbreaking and, from my experience, diversity is valued and represented.
cons: Abbott gives nearly free reign to their various divisions and the VPs and directors of various departments. If you get stuck with a bad VP or director, your career progression comes to a halt. Those situations are lead to being incredibly overworked while being vastly underpaid, but a blind eye turned to to the expectation of 40 hours/week. I became accustomed to 15 hours/day, with the sometimes off day on weekends, with no additional compensation, no basic appreciation, and no faith that my career would progress. This is very department-based and management-based.

review_title: job description was entirely different from actual role
pros:
No transparency, a lot of promise from the job description but fell short of expectations. 
they do spend a great deal on promoting themselves as a brand
They do have good vacation but this is a audit friendly company , hence you have to schedule them only when there is no audits which is rare.
cons:
the job description that I applied to and got selected was IT related but the team that I joined was a some record keeping and doc control (more clerical).
there was one aspect of the role that was IT related but not all of it.(which accounted for <40% of the role)
the hiring manager retired and the replacement manager although realized the need for the role but decided on molding me into her area of expertise.
She had a dislike for me from the beginning very evident in the way she picked on me, she even gave me partial achieved performance review just 5 months into the job.
Her mocking at my IT specific skills proved that she didn't take time to know my background and also her knowledge in the subject.
She always took sides with the other team member, wonder if it was because I was a person of color. Although there is HR related course on unconscious bias, diversity and stuff, you could definitely see a shift in behavior if you are white. There is a diversity program but no inclusion and equity.
Also got to experience some uncivil behavior from manager of manufacturing, he would send emails that bad mouthed you and make it appear like an oopsy.
I guess Abbott should invest in some behavioral and team building workshops, as from my experience they are very unprofessional and unpolished warehouse like environment. 
I do thank the manager for creating a hostile environment, if not for her I wouldn't have been forced look outside of Abbott and be in a much better state of bliss.
